verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and all his army, with all the kingdoms of the earth under his dominion, and all the peoples, were fighting against Jerusalem and all its towns:
verses.comment: This verse establishes the historical context for Jeremiah’s prophecy—Babylon’s siege under Nebuchadnezzar. It highlights the scope of Babylon’s power and foreshadows impending judgment.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: Go and speak to Zedekiah king of Judah and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD says: I am about to give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shall burn it with fire.’
verses.comment: Zedekiah, the last king of Judah, is warned of Jerusalem’s inevitable fall. The prophecy’s clarity shows God’s sovereignty and commitment to just judgment.

verses.text: And you shall not escape from his hand, but shall certainly be captured and given into his hand. You shall see the king of Babylon face to face, and speak with him mouth to mouth, and you shall go to Babylon.
verses.comment: Jeremiah prophesies Zedekiah’s personal encounter with Nebuchadnezzar, fulfilled in history (see Jer 39:5–7). God’s justice is both personal and national.

verses.text: Yet hear the word of the LORD, O Zedekiah king of Judah: Thus says the LORD concerning you, ‘You shall not die by the sword.’
verses.comment: Despite the judgment on Jerusalem, a measure of mercy is shown to Zedekiah. God’s justice is often tempered by mercy, pointing to deeper spiritual realities fulfilled in Christ’s ministry.

verses.text: You shall die in peace. And as they burned incense for your forefathers, the kings who came before you, so they shall burn incense for you, saying, ‘Alas, lord!’ For I have spoken the word, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Customs of honoring kings in death are referenced. God’s word remains true and sovereign even in times of sorrow. Here, the idea of incense and funerary rites prefigures the use of rituals to honor those who served in positions of intercessory leadership.

verses.text: Then Jeremiah the prophet spoke all these words to Zedekiah king of Judah, in Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s obedience to proclaim God’s message, even in the face of danger, is a model for prophetic faithfulness (see 2 Tim. 4:2).

verses.text: when the army of the king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and all the remaining cities of Judah—Lachish and Azekah. Only these fortified cities were left of the cities of Judah.
verses.comment: The fall of all but two strongholds emphasizes the completeness of Babylon’s conquest and teaches humility before divine judgment.

verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD, after King Zedekiah made a covenant with all the people in Jerusalem to proclaim liberty to them,
verses.comment: The theme of covenant and liberty echoes the Jubilee law in Leviticus, prefiguring freedom through Christ (see Luke 4:18).

verses.text: that everyone should free his Hebrew slave, male or female, so that no one should enslave his fellow Jew.
verses.comment: The command to release Hebrew slaves reflects God’s concern for justice and freedom. Spiritually, it mirrors the freedom from sin offered in the new covenant. See Galatians 5:1.

verses.text: And they obeyed—all the officials and all the people who had entered into the covenant—freeing their male and female slaves, so that no one held another in bondage any longer. Then they obeyed and set them free.
verses.comment: Initially, all respond faithfully to the command. This moment of obedience shows how communal submission to God’s law leads to blessing.

verses.text: But afterward they turned and took back the male and female slaves whom they had freed, and brought them back into subjection as slaves.
verses.comment: Israel’s reversal shows the hardness of heart in breaking a solemn covenant. Covenants are enduring, mirroring the permanence expected of spiritual commitments (see Hebrews 9:15).

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah:
verses.comment: God responds to breach of covenant, highlighting the seriousness of disobedience.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: I made a covenant with your forefathers when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage, saying:
verses.comment: References Israel’s origin story and their original covenantal relationship with God, typological for the deliverance through Christ.

verses.text: At the end of seven years, each of you must set free his fellow Hebrew who has been sold to you and has served you six years; you must let him go free from you. But your forefathers did not listen or incline their ear to Me.
verses.comment: God refers to Mosaic law (Jubilee), emphasizing obedience to sacred commands. The number seven is spiritually significant for completion and covenant.

verses.text: You recently turned and did what was right in My eyes by proclaiming liberty, each to his neighbor, and you made a covenant before Me in the house that is called by My name.
verses.comment: Obedience followed by covenant renewal in the temple points to the importance of public worship and covenant-making, echoing the communal aspects of faith.

verses.text: But then you turned back and profaned My name when each took back his male and female slaves whom you had set free at their desire, and you forced them again to become your slaves.
verses.comment: Breaking covenant not only violates man, but profanes the name of the Lord, reflecting the spiritual gravity of covenant-breaking.

verses.text: Therefore, thus says the LORD: You have not obeyed Me by proclaiming liberty, each to his brother and to his neighbor; therefore, I proclaim liberty for you—to the sword, to pestilence, and to famine, declares the LORD. I will make you a horror to all the kingdoms of the earth.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is just: failed liberty brings liberty to judgment. This reversal shows the seriousness of sin and foreshadows the need for a greater Redeemer.

verses.text: And I will give the men who transgressed My covenant, who have not fulfilled the words of the covenant that they made before Me, when they cut the calf in two and passed between its parts—
verses.comment: The cutting of the calf symbolizes the seriousness of covenant. The act is symbolic of accepting curses if the covenant is broken (see Gen. 15:17).

verses.text: the officials of Judah, the officials of Jerusalem, the court officers, the priests, and all the people of the land who passed between the parts of the calf—
verses.comment: Leaders and people alike are accountable to the covenant, emphasizing unity of responsibility. The inclusion of priests highlights the sacrificial nature of leadership and points to Christ as the true High Priest.

verses.text: I will give them into the hand of their enemies and into the hand of those who seek their lives. Their bodies shall be food for the birds of the sky and the beasts of the earth.
verses.comment: Divine judgment manifests physically and spiritually. The reference to unburied bodies is a sign of utter rejection, demonstrating the seriousness of covenant violation.

verses.text: I will give Zedekiah king of Judah and his officials into the hand of their enemies, into the hand of those who seek their lives, and into the hand of the army of the king of Babylon, which has withdrawn from you.
verses.comment: Though the Babylonian army had temporarily left, God makes clear that Zedekiah’s fate is sealed by covenant-breaking, underlining both temporal and spiritual consequences.

verses.text: Behold, I will command, declares the LORD, and will bring them back to this city. They will fight against it, capture it, and burn it with fire. And I will make the towns of Judah a desolation, without inhabitant.
verses.comment: God’s word is sure; despite temporary relief, judgment will come. The burning of the city foreshadows apocalyptic themes, which speak to both temporal punishment and eschatological purification, pointing spiritually to eventual renewal and restoration promised in prophetic literature. See Revelation 21:1–4 for the ultimate hope.
